title: Baby owlets prove they are real lovebirds as they snuggle up together in Indian national park
text:
Advertisement

This is the adorable moment that a pair of loved-up owlets sharing a snuggle in India were caught on camera.

Shreya Singha Ray spent a week watching the Spotted owlets at Tadoba National Park, India, before snapping the two speckled animals perched on a branch.

They are seen craning their small heads and nestling into each other as their eyes flicker shut - and could be 'mutually preening' which involves bird's perching close to strengthen their relationship.

The photograph, 34, said: 'When I saw the owlets sitting close to each other, I was hoping that they would display such affection for a few moments at least.'

'When they actually did, fortunately I was ready at that moment. Their expression of affection was really very sweet and adorable to look at.'

During mating season, owls hooting will increase as the males try to figure out the proximity of females, lure them over and perhaps offer food to court them. They will then mark their territory to prevent other males from stealing their mate.

Spotted Owlets are distinct in their patterned fur, arched white brows and deep golden-yellow eyes which indicate that they hunt during the day.They are commonly found in southern Asia from Iran to Vietnam except Thailand and Malaysia.

Among Tadoba National Park's residents is the sloth bear, hyena, jackal, wild dog and sambar.

There are 195 bird species including those endangered and 74 species of butterflies.
